name: Gravimetric moisture determination
description: In soil science: method used to measure the amount of water in a soil by weighing the sample before and after drying it in an oven at a temperature of 100–110 degrees Celsius. (International Glossary of Hydrology 661 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Neutron probe
description: Geophysical record obtained by lowering a tool containing a radioactive element emitting neutrons and a neutron detector into a borehole, in order to measure the moisture content and hence the porosity of the geological formation. (International Glossary of Hydrology 999 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Electrical resistance blocks (Porous blocks)
description: Porous blocks are made of gypsum, glass/gypsum matrix, ceramic, nylon and fibreglass. They are buried at the depth of measurement desired. Over time, the blocks come to equilibrium with the moisture content in the surrounding soil. Therefore, the subsequent measurement is related to soil water tension. In the case of electrical resistance blocks, two electrodes are buried inside the block with a cable extending to the surface. The electrical resistance is measured between the two electrodes using a meter attached to the cable. Higher resistance readings mean lower block water content and higher soilwater tension (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 4.5.3.2 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Tensiometer
description: Instrument consisting of a porous cup, inserted in the soil, connected to a manometer by a water-filled tube, used to measure capillary tension or suction. (International Glossary of Hydrology 1491 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Time domain reflectometry (TDR)
description: Technique used to estimate water content in unsaturated materials based on variations in their dielectric properties. (International Glossary of Hydrology 1515 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Echo sounder
description: Instrument using the reflection of an acoustic signal from the bottom of a water body to determine the depth. (ISO 772) (International Glossary of Hydrology 448 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Frequency domain reflectometry
description: This approach uses radio frequency waves to measure soil capacitance. The soil acts as the dielectric completing a capacitance circuit, which is part of a feedback loop of a high-frequency transistor oscillator (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 4.5.2.3 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Gamma-ray attenuation
description: The method consists of concurrently lowering a gamma-ray source (generally Caesium 137) and a gamma-ray detector (scintillator-photomultiplier) down a pair of parallel access tubes that have been installed in the soil. At each measurement level, the signal can be translated into the apparent wet density of the soil or, if the apparent dry bulk density of the soil is known, the signal can be converted into a measure of the volumetric soil-moisture content. (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 4.5.2.4 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Non-recording gauge
description: Several types of non-recording gauge for measuring stage exists. The most common are: graduated vertical or inclined staff gauge, wire-weight gauge, graduated rod, tape or point gauge and maximum-stage gauge (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 5.1.2.1 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Staff gauge
description: Graduated vertical scale, fixed to a staff or structure, on which the water level may be read (syn. vertical gauge). (International Glossary of Hydrology 1409 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Inclined gauge
description: Non-vertical water-level gauge which is graduated to indicate vertical heights. (International Glossary of Hydrology 792 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Wire-weight gauge
description: Manual stage gauge consisting of a fine cable or wire attached to a weight which is lowered to the water surface in order to determine its position below a fixed above-surface point. (International Glossary of Hydrology 1690 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Point gauge
description: Level measurement gauge, the essential element of which is a pointed rod that is lowered until it touches the water surface. (ISO 772) (International Glossary of Hydrology 1092 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Maximum-stage gauge
description: A maximum-stage gauge is used for obtaining the elevation of the flood crest by the adherence of regranulated cork to a graduated staff held in a fixed position with relation to the datum. (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 5.1.2.1 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Recording gauge
description: Device that automatically records the water level as detected by a sensor, either continuously or at regular time intervals (syn. limnigraph, stage recorder, water-level recorder). (International Glossary of Hydrology 1622 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Wire-float recording gauge (hydrograph)
description: Gauge consisting of a float which rises and falls with changes in the water level; this movement being transmitted to a recording or indicating device. (International Glossary of Hydrology 539 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Pressure-actuated recording gauge
description: Various pressure-actuated recording gauges in common use operate on the principle that static pressure at a fixed point in the stream is directly proportional to the head of liquid above the point. This relation is described by the following equation: Water level = (P_static – P_atm ) C, where P_static is the pressure in bar on a fixed spot in the water column, P_atm is the atmospheric pressure in bar on the surface of the water column, and C is a factor of the water’s net weight (C = 10.2 for freshwater at 20°C), which changes with the temperature and salinity of the water. (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 5.1.2.2 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Velocity-area method
description: Method of determining the discharge of a stream by measuring the velocity of the flowing water and the depth of the water at a number of points over the cross-section, and summing the products of mean velocities by elemental areas. (International Glossary of Hydrology 1590 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Float gauging
description: Measurement of the velocity of a stream by means of a float or velocity rod. (ISO 772) (International Glossary of Hydrology 540 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Dilution gauging
description: Method for determining the discharge of a stream by measuring the degree of dilution, caused by the flowing water, of an added tracer solution (syn. chemical gauging, tracer dilution gauging). (International Glossary of Hydrology 384 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Slope-area method
description: Method of discharge determination in a reach which is based on the surface slope, the reach roughness, the wetted perimeters and the flow areas of the various wetted cross-sections in the reach. (ISO 772) (International Glossary of Hydrology 1334 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Measuring weir
description: Device or structure across a stream which causes a free or submerged fall and is used for determining discharge. (International Glossary of Hydrology 938 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Flume
description: Man-made channel with clearly specified shape and dimensions which may be used for the measurement of discharge. (International Glossary of Hydrology 579 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Stage-discharge relation
description: Relationship between water level and discharge for a river cross-section, which may be expressed as a curve, a table or an equation. (International Glossary of Hydrology 1410 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Current meter
description: Instrument for measuring water velocity. (ISO 772) (syn. flowmeter) (International Glossary of Hydrology 321 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Cup-type current meter
description: Current meter whose rotor is composed of a wheel fitted with cups turning on a vertical axis. (International Glossary of Hydrology 320 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Propeller-type current meter
description: Current meter in which the rotor is a propeller rotating around an axis parallel to the flow (International Glossary of Hydrology 1137 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Acoustic (ultrasonic) velocity meter
description: System that uses the difference in travel time of acoustic (ultrasonic) pulses between transducers in a stream to determine the mean velocity on the signal path. (International Glossary of Hydrology 20 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Acoustic doppler current profiler (ADCP)
description: ADCP instruments can be mounted on a moving vessel, such as an inflatable boat. The instrument uses an acoustic doppler transducer to measure water velocity, depth and vessel path simultaneously to compute discharge. As an ADCP instrument processes the signal reflected off the particles in the water, it divides the water column into a number of discrete segments stacked in the vertical. These segments are called depth cells. An ADCP instrument determines the velocity and direction of each depth cell. At the same time the signal from the bottom, called bottom-track, measures the speed and direction of the boat. Once the profile is finished the ADCP calculates the total discharge. At least four transects are recommended to calculate the discharge at a site. The actual river discharge estimate will then be the average of the N individual transects discharge values (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 5.3.7.5.3 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Acoustic doppler current meter
description: An acoustic Doppler instrument measures the velocity of the water using a physical principle called the Doppler shift. This states that if a source of sound is moving relative to the receiver, the frequency of the sound at the receiver is shifted from the transmit frequency. The instrument transmits an acoustic pulse of energy into the water which is reflected off particles suspended in, and moving with, the water and some of it returns to the instrument. The instrument measures the Doppler shift (change in frequency) of the reflected energy and uses this to compute the velocity of the water relative to the instrument. The reflected pulses have a frequency (Doppler) shift proportional to the velocities of the scatterers they are travelling in along the acoustic beam: V = ( F_d / 2 F_0 ) C, where F_d is the Doppler shifted frequency received at the transducer, F_0 is the transducer transmit frequency, C is the sound speed, and V is the scatterer (water) velocity . (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 5.3.7.5.4 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Optical or nuclear suspended-sediment gauge
description: The working principle of these instruments is that a visible light of X-ray emitted by a source with constant intensity is scattered and/or absorbed by the suspended-sediment particles. The decrease of intensity measured by a photoelectric or nuclear detector situated at constant distance from the source is proportional to the sediment concentration, if other relevant characteristics of water and sediment (chemical, mineral composition, etc.) remain unchanged. (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 5.5.3.5 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Gravimetric sediment measurement
description: Method of estimating the total sediment by allowing the sediment to settle in a container, siphoning off the supernatant water, carefully transferring all the sediment from the container on to filter paper, then drying the sample and determining the mass of total sediment. (ISO 772) (International Glossary of Hydrology 661 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=8209)

name: Displacement method
description: The displacement method involves determining the difference in weight between a sample of sediment-laden water and an equal volume of clear water. The dry weight of sediment is computed by the following equation: W_s = k (W_ws - W_w), where k = q_s/(q-q_s), in which W_s is the weight of sediment to be determined in grams; W_ws is the weight of the specific gravity flask plus the weight of sediment water mixture in grams; W_w is the weight of the specific gravity flask plus the weight of clear water with volume and temperature equal to that of the sediment-water mixture; during weighing the water temperature should be constant; q_s is density of sediment particles; q is density of water; during weighing the water temperature should be constant (WMO Manual on Sediment Management and Measurement https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=1709)

name: Water discharge-sediment discharge rating curve
description: A continuous record of suspended-sediment discharge is computed from a record of stream discharges and systematic samples of suspended-sediment concentration. The samples should be taken daily during periods of low and mean flow and more frequently during floods (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 5.5.3.5 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Water discharge-bed material rating curve
description: Measurements of bed-material discharge are made at various stream discharges so that a rating may be prepared showing the relationship between stream discharge and bed-material discharge. (WMO Guide to Hydrological Practices, 2008 5.5.4.2 https://library.wmo.int/doc_num.php?explnum_id=10473)

name: Ultrasonic ranging
description: Transmission of an ultrasonic pulse towards the target and listening for a return echo from that target.

name: Graduated device
description: Manual measurement or observation made with a graduated fixed stake, a sturdy ruler, or an extendable graduated rod.

path: \Terrestrial\Water equivalent of snow cover\Snow pillows and snow scales
name: Snow pillows and snow scales
description: Weighing of snow-cover mass per unit area.

name: Laser ranging
description: Emission of a modulated beam of light in the visible spectrum to determine the distance to a target by comparing the phase information from the reflected beam.

name: inapplicable
description: None of the codes in the table are applicable in the context of this particular observation.

name: unknown
description: The measurement/observing method is unknown.
